I started walking north, until I got to a point where the subway was operating or I could get a cab or just kept walking - I honestly don’t remember how I made it home to Silver Spring.
Out in the sea of people on the street, after a period of group commiseration with colleagues and strangers alike, I decided I needed to get to my family ASAP.

I remember discussing whether we should walk to the Pentagon to help — it would probably have taken an hour just to get there on foot — with Damon Silvers, who works at the AFL-CIO to this day as policy director.
I Street and 16th Street were filled with people streaming out of buildings. The subway had been shut down. Most of us didn’t have cars, and anyway the streets were clogged.

At some point the building was evacuated. People realized that the White House was a target and we were in danger. I remember gathering my things as my colleagues who were emergency building captains urged us to hasten outside, but once we were there, there was nowhere to go.

We were all wandering around the 8th Floor in a daze, not knowing what to do. A while later, we went back into the conference room with its huge south-facing windows and looked sharply to the right, or west, where you could see a huge plume of smoke — the Pentagon on fire.

I remember going down the hall to Arlene Holt-Baker’s office with her, because she had a TV. We started watching what was happening, and saw the completely incredible sight on live television of the second commercial jet hitting the south tower.

The image in my head and I bet the heads of others as well was of a biplane or other little tourist plane, because there had been a recent incident like that. Maybe then or maybe a few minutes later, Bob said, “I guess we should finish up and adjourn the meeting.”
But Bob sort of cocked his head and said to the group but also to no one in particular, because it was so odd, “Hmmm, a plane hit the World Trade Center.”

President Sweeney’s chief of staff, Bob Welsh, was presiding, as usual. I remember Bob’s secretary, as she would still have been called then, Linda Hall, entering the room and passing Bob a note. That wasn’t uncommon.

I was the Assistant Director of Organizing at the AFL-CIO. By 9/11, I had already worked there for six years, since John Sweeney had become president of the labor federation in October, 1995. So it was as regular a part of my life as almost anything, those management meetings.

September 11, 2001 was a Tuesday. I remember because that’s the day the senior staff of the @AFLCIO met in the executive conference room on the 8th floor at 815 16th Street. The room has one of the great views in Washington, overlooking the White House across Lafayette Square.
